history.content:
You can't actually learn optimization by watching anything. Just like you can't learn skiing by watching skiing videos. You have to hit the slopes to actually learn. Some videos can help you as you actually practice. The most they can do *before* you practice is to reduce anxiety or increase enthusiasm.

Probability is the same way. Or programming. No amount of reading about probability or programming or watching videos will let you learn. You have to do problems and respectively, write and debug code. Not clear if watching videos is a good use of time as compared to sleeping or physical exercise in terms of payoffs in taking an optimization class the next semester.

That's why taking courses in these critical areas is crucial --- they provide curated homeworks and projects. That's why courses like 16ab and 70 and everything mathy have a lot of homework for you to do --- to get you used to building strong foundations. With foundations in place, you can then teach yourself lots of things.

If you have a lot of mathematical and algorithmic practice from other classes (physics?? control and SP classes?), then take the textbook for 127 and read and do the problems. Prof. Boyd's course at Stanford has some slides and things online that can help complement the book.  But why do this before taking the class instead of during class?

Stanford's CVX 101 is a MOOC of their EE 364a course, which I've heard a lot of good things about (including from Berkeley profs. who did grad school at Stanford!): https://lagunita.stanford.edu/courses/Engineering/CVX101/Winter2014/about
Stanford's CVX 101 is a MOOC of their EE 364a course, which I've heard a lot of good things about: https://lagunita.stanford.edu/courses/Engineering/CVX101/Winter2014/about

Hi I am just thinking about watching some similar courses to EECS127 during the winter break and fail to find any, any suggestion of similar courses or ways to prepare one for the course would be very helpful. Thanks!
history.subject: Resources for self-learning EECS127
